text:
<@UPUBAM63X> Saw these posts in the unisonlang slack, thought about your quest.

Sami Badawi--
> A noob impression.
> I have spent years trying to wrap my head around Haskell. I read the Unison Language Reference and I am baffled how short it is.
> There are so few constructs. I feel I am missing something. If not, why is Unison so much simpler?
Will--
> a shocking proportion of haskell’s surface area is essentially just sugar for a very simple core. I highly recommend this talk from SPJ: <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uR_VzYxvbxg>
Anthony Coates--
> Perhaps "shocking" is the wrong way to look at it. Simon et al maintain that small core because it makes it easier to maintain Haskell, and also because it makes it easier to determine when a new addition to the language is some genuinely new functionality, or just a new or more convenient way to use the existing functionality.
...
Sami Badawi--
> That SPJ talk was great.
> I think that the algebraic effects deal with one of Haskell's big weaknesses.
> Monad transformers is a pretty complicated construct for dealing with normal problems.
Will--
> i agree, that’s definitely an area where you can tell that haskell is a “playground” for ideas. hopefully delimited continuations can eventually subsume a lot of the different, complex effect systems
Link: <https://unisonlanguage.slack.com/archives/CLKV43YE4/p1612034587039000>

elements.text:
Saw these posts in the unisonlang slack, thought about your quest.

Sami Badawi--

A noob impression.
I have spent years trying to wrap my head around Haskell. I read the Unison Language Reference and I am baffled how short it is.
There are so few constructs. I feel I am missing something. If not, why is Unison so much simpler?
Will--
a shocking proportion of haskell’s surface area is essentially just sugar for a very simple core. I highly recommend this talk from SPJ:
Anthony Coates--

Perhaps "shocking" is the wrong way to look at it. Simon et al maintain that small core because it makes it easier to maintain Haskell, and also because it makes it easier to determine when a new addition to the language is some genuinely new functionality, or just a new or more convenient way to use the existing functionality.

...
Sami Badawi--

That SPJ talk was great.
I think that the algebraic effects deal with one of Haskell's big weaknesses.
Monad transformers is a pretty complicated construct for dealing with normal problems.
Will--
i agree, that’s definitely an area where you can tell that haskell is a “playground” for ideas. hopefully delimited continuations can eventually subsume a lot of the different, complex effect systems

text:
Haskell is amazing, I hardly understand enough of it to have any opinion about it taken seriously. I think Haskell is among the best programming languages I've ever used, but there's something really nice about the F#/ML take on it too. That's what bothers me about haskell the most I think, is that I've been ingrained to write code differently for years. The runner up is doing production level work.
I peeped unison - I don't really know what's going on there. I asked some serious FP people about it and they were like "it's cool but yea in progress".
